column1: Before 1 July 2022, will the US impose sanctions on any Chinese person or entity for actions related to the COVID-19 pandemic?
column6: ['Economic Policy', 'Foreign Policy', 'US Policy']
Only two days away from 7/1
Sorry mixed up 0% and 100%. Should go back to school ;-)
Too late too hard and too useless
No recent news updates regarding this.
Seems very unlikely because the global attention has shifted from Covid to Ukraine.
There would be no real benefit for the US to impose sanctions for what is still considered an unfounded accusation.

The US has not sanctioned China since 2020 - meaning all the current sanctions were by Trump, zero by Biden. To sanction them for covid-19 actions would only re-shine a spotlight on gain of function cover ups during a midterm election year.

Though not truly 0%, I would estimate this is much closer to 0.1% than 1%. In addition to lack of evidence, there does not appear to be any incentive for sanctions on China in the current geopolitical climate.
Made it to 0%. We are in Apr and the chances that such will occur are close to none. There are no visible actions currently running that could lead to sanctions.

There are no official statements based on evidence that the virus was artificially created in China, and the actual chances to obtain such are close to none. I am still giving a 1%, as there are still few months till the deadline and you never know what could happen. There is a very small probability that someone will come up with something. A 0% leaves no chance at all for such a possibility.

Still aligned with my original forecast and the reasons first stated. Am attempting to find news that would counter that belief, however the administration is consumed with China's support of Russia in the Russian-Ukraine conflict, and therefore will be less likely to impose any sanctions regarding COVID-19.

The outbreak of the coronavirus pandemic is too long ago, compared with the general interest in amicable US China relationships. There are several scenarios in which I can imagine sanctions being made: 1. China can be proven to be responsible for the pandemic. 2. China has maliciously attempted to spread the pandemic.

I doubt the US Governmet will take any action that will increase the China - US conflict level for an event that happended two years ago. However, if there appear real evidence for harmful wrongdoing in China related to the icenption of COVID, there may be actions taken
Not very likely.
There is no solid evidence establishing culpability against any individual or organization there and it certainly will not appear by July 1.
All in
Not going to happen.

The amount of newly-discovered details needed to emerge to make this happen by July sounds about as implausible as the plot line of a Michael Bay film. Plus, with tensions mounting with Russia over Ukraine (and China’s expressed support for Russia), it’s safe to say that things will continue to be iffy with US & China for some time to come regardless of what happens with Ukraine. Unless we have absolutely proven and indisputable evidence against China on this matter, I don’t see the current administration imposing sanctions on China or a citizen of China for Covid-19-related actions anytime soon, if ever.
Passage of time.
This could only happen under a Trump Administration

It appears, but may be reading incorrectly that we have only sanctioned China 9 times as a whole (individuals are counted separately within a subset of those 9 instances), since the establishment of the PRC. And the individuals we have sanctioned have been done based on fact of human rights abuses or breaking trade laws (approximating here). Finally, since the beginning of COVID and into the current administration, where the US has pressed the Chinese government a bit and scientists for answers, it hasn't held China at all accountable. The US, I don't believe will have an appetite to do that now based on all the other events and conversations happening with China, such as Taiwan reunification.

The current administration has been less aggressive with China related to COVID. There is also a relative lack of clear evidence to pinpoint the source of complicity for Chinese individuals or corporations. Sanctions may also have undesirable consequences for foreign investments that would affect both the US and China.

I don't think COVID related sanctions against Chinese persons and/or entities are going to be imposed. And when this might happen then not before 1 July 2022. But why I do think that way? 1. We still have a pandemic situation and certainly we still will have it when July 2022 comes around. As long politics is dealing with the pandemic itself, there is not so much attention going into political activities of the PRC. When the pandemic is over however and political actors and scientists are more looking into the origin of the Corona virus (I personally think - at the moment at least - too much points towards the lap leak hypothesis to completely rule it out) and all the censoring and covering up by Chinese authorities and politicians will come under much more scrutiny, but not so soon. Scientific and political analysis and its results will still take some time. 2. When I think about sanctions, which have been imposed in let's say the last ten years, then terrorists, war criminals, Nord Stream 2, crimes against humanity, money laundry or other activities of organised crime and such come to my mind. And all these are purposefully committed with excessively and continuing brutal force or, in case of Nordstream 2, have serious geopolitical ramifications and when it comes to crime and organised crime, then sanctions come into place when politics is too much entangeled in it. None of that is true for COVID and how the PRC is dealing with it. That doesn't mean the CCP isn't trying to use the pandemic for political gains but that is something what many other political actors also do and what is (unfortunately) part of the political game. So I'm not expecting COVID-19 related US sanctions against China within the next half year. Please let me know what you thing of my thoughts especially when you disagree or think I've missed something. Thank you!
I think sanctions are highly unlikely given the economic impacts it could have.
Given that epidemiologists still cant pinpoint the true source of the virus tells me they actually can not find it, or adequate pressure has already been applied to the right organizations.
At this time with the current administration, I do not believe this would happen.
If the US has not already, probably will not happen
2022_02.22. As of today, there is very low probability for such action. Also there are no visible official activities that potentially could conduct towards such development. Keep a 1% probability.
More unlikely now.
There is no rational scientific evidence to sanction China over the Covid-19 virus. @ed321
Ed321
Lack of evidence.
China has given the US a plethora of reasons to impose sanctions and none of them have been acted on. There are many other reasons much more likely to cause sanctions to be imposed.
Highly unlikely. Will never get the evidence, even if it exists. Wouldn't look good to publicize anyway.

Cannot think of a relevant authority or reference case. Other sanctions are for human rights, WMDs proliferation, corruption, I think. So likelihood seems very low, but US politics seems it can't be a zero chance - Congress could mandate sanctions and the Administration might decide to follow though.
US restricts trade with a dozen more Chinese technology firms - BBC News https://www.bbc.com/news/business-59412139 Thu, 25 Nov 2021 03:42:49 GMT c7947ab34c2d932c4cadd867cc3a986c

Nov 24, 2021. As the time passes it becomes less probable US will impose sanctions. There is no public information which might suggest a new investigation is running or planned. Today I changed from 4%, which means already a low probability, to 2%.
There are no indications of any sanctions IRT this topic are moving forward.
No change

Recent WHO investigation into origins of the pandemic was recently announced, but while tensions are increasing between US and China I think it is more probable that if sanction would be imposed, it would related to other matters, not related to COVID-19. At 5% because Biden has only used sanctions against China for national security measures so far, and less so for political purposes.

China Opposes U.S. Threat to Impose Sanctions on Ethiopia - Bloomberg https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-09-23/china-opposes-u-s-threat-to-impose-sanctions-on-ethiopia Thu, 23 Sep 2021 10:11:32 GMT db8a1cdbbd58799413df31de7b224cf1

Sanctions generally target foreign countries and regimes, terrorists, human rights violators, narcotics traffickers, proliferators of WMD, "and other threats to the national security, foreign policy or economy of the United​ States." At this time, there is no clear evidence that COVID was purposefully released to affect/threaten US security and economic interests. In addition, the US has not previously sanctioned any person or state for unwittingly releasing a chemical or biological agent. Another concern is that if the US sanctions China, China may implement sanctions against the US, which could negatively affect US economic interests.

My inclination is that the likelihood of this occurring is very slim, 1% or 1 in 100 chances (in the 1 parallel alternate universe if you will). After a scan of news stories about "holding China accountable for COVID19," the most recent public statement was by former Secretary Pompeo on 4 August 2021 (Mike Pompeo Pushes Joe Biden to Hold China Accountable for COVID, https://www.newsweek.com/mike-pompeo-pushes-joe-biden-hold-china-accountable-covid-1616131) The only other more recent item I found was the introduction of a measure in the US Senate by Senator Marshall (not a well known Senator except in his state of Kansas) on 9 Sep 2021 proposing a way forward to hold China accountable (Sen. Marshall Releases Path Forward on COVID Origins Investigation and Holding China Accountable, https://www.marshall.senate.gov/press-releases/sen-marshall-releases-path-forward-on-covid-origins-investigation-and-holding-china-accountable/). Given the current higher profile topics on Capitol Hill of the pending budget crisis and $3.5 Trillion spending package, any discussion of holding China accountable is going to disappear almost completely from the news cycle (as if it hasn't already) and the attention of the US government. It is not likely to regain traction after the current debates are settled as there will be the next thing to focus on, not the old thing that few of the current elected officials really wanted to address anyway.

It looks the Biden administration is not considering this a current priority. The subject might become hot again pending on the US-China relations or the impact of new Covid infections. Still, as the time is passing, the chances to get evidences to support this are decreasing.

diplomatic and financial relation between US and China will not be compromised- - China taking strict measures to combat COVID 19 - COVID 19 might not be the top health issue in mid 2022 with vaccination and screening -
Downward revision based on passage of time - about 9 months left.

Though there is strong bipartisan domestic support for action against China for perceived discretions, I do not think that the material conditions exist for simple sanctions. More likely, this war drive will reach critical mass farther in the future than July 2022.
Some interesting reading: - https://bit.ly/2VtKAe6 - https://bit.ly/2YOENBr - http://bit.ly/3l5bjGM
Down slightly with result of Biden's request to intelligence community
Not after the report from DNI . https://www.dni.gov/index.php/newsroom/reports-publications/reports-publications-2021/item/2236-unclassified-summary-of-assessment-on-covid-19-origins
The US Intelligence report was inconclusive. Hard to make an argument for sanctions without evidence.

"US intelligence report requested by President Biden into the origins of the coronavirus pandemic is inconclusive". As mentioned before, it is very difficult to obtain evidence that would involve the Wuhan laboratory and it is not in China's interest to support such a conclusion. On the other hand, someone who hasn't done anything wrong would normally have no problem cooperating with investigators just to prove it. Probably the deal will be closed behind closed doors at G20 meeting in October. https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-58329980 https://www.wsj.com/articles/biden-to-receive-report-on-coronavirus-origins-but-challenges-persist-in-how-to-deal-with-china-11629825758
Looking increasingly a 'No'; https://wapo.st/3BdzVU2
No change.

Based on President Biden's statement, the 90-day review started on or about May 26, 2021 [https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/statements-releases/2021/05/26/statement-by-president-joe-biden-on-the-investigation-into-the-origins-of-covid-19/]. The 90-day mark is August 24, 2021, which is early next week.

There might be some momentum back on China from government when the Beijing Olympics come back within the time frame of this question. This may be accelerated by any negative effects of the Delta variant spread.
No change; still surprised that the crowd is so low.
https://gallagher.house.gov/media/press-releases/gallagher-introduces-bill-sanction-china-lack-covid-19-transparency
The pot calling the kettle black.
President Harris doesn't have the b@!!$.

It might be expected that US Intelligence will require more time to investigate. With China rejecting any foreign forensic investigation and keep pushing on Covid's "natural" origin it is hard to see how US Intelligence will come up with solid evidence. Unless there might be someone in China who would disclose such despite the risks, or US intelligence network in China is that strong and could get documents on this matter (and would take the risk to lose part of the network). Getting evidence by hacking the Chinese servers is very unlikely as China had enough time to remove any evidence, and even such would exist it would be treated as a top secret and heavily protected, with very low chances to penetrate the firewall. And finally, in case US Intelligence report comes to conclusion the Covid originates from the Wuhan lab, would Biden administration make it public? Would Biden want to bring Sino-American relations to a breakpoint, making China responsible for millions of human casualties and trillions of dollars spent fighting on Covid? That's unlikely that Biden would risk a political and economic WW crisis. There is also the possibility of closed doors discussions between Biden and Xi Jinping during October G20 summit in Rome. With China taking some commitments the discussions on Covid's origin might come to an inconclusive end.
Not this administration.

This seems quite unlikely. The "lab escape" scenario has mostly been relegated to conspiracy theorists, with very little evidence. Under the previous administration I would have ranked this much higher, but the Biden admin is publicly committed to the international order and rule of law, which I think means they will not issue sanctions unless malfeasance is quite definitively proven... which there's really no evidence for.
I think it is unlikely the US will find any direct evidence against China. Only way is for a whistleblower to defect to the US. Highly unlikely.
@Jprice94 @mkarbowsky @Pablo_Vargas
China imposes sanctions on US officials - BBC News https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-china-57950720 Fri, 23 Jul 2021 22:55:03 GMT
With no additional hard evidence except conjecture - only evidence likely held by Chinese authorities - what is the rationale for doing this?

Increasing my forecast due to (1) China's rejection of second investigation to understand the origins of Covid-19 [https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-china-57926368], (2) Recent sanctions from US on China and China on US related to Hong Kong [https://www.ft.com/content/2e120dc0-a1ed-4327-b71a-52cdbe3169f0].
Passage of time

China has rejected the proposal from the World Health Organization to carry out the second phase of the investigation into the origins of the coronavirus, which would include inspections of laboratories and markets in the city of Wuhan, Reuters reported on Thursday Jul 22, 2021. I increase the probability from 10% to 15% and wait to see the US response.

The U.S. is willing to sanction China for their cyberattacks (https://www.cnn.com/2021/07/19/politics/china-biden-ransomware/index.html). However, sanctions regarding COVID-19 seem much less likely and would most likely occur after a multilateral investigation that found wrongdoing (such as a possible lab leak). As of July 2021 a second WHO investigation seems relatively unlikely (https://news.yahoo.com/china-opposes-call-second-investigation-220000944.html) thus risk of U.S. sanctions on China for COVID-19 are low.

US issues sanctions, warns businesses of risks in China and Hong Kong as Beijing promises to 'respond strongly' - CNN https://www.cnn.com/2021/07/16/politics/us-china-hong-kong-sanctions/index.html Sat, 17 Jul 2021 03:24:00 GMT

I doubt the US has an incentive to impose sanctions on a health-related topic, which has also affected the Chinese population considerably. The only potential for sanctions would be in the case of obstruction to scientific or humanitarian missions. However, when the WHO organised a mission to China to investigate the origins of the pandemic, no mention of sanctions was made when the mission was delayed by the Chinese authorities.
WHO calls for more transparency from PRC; https://reut.rs/3koXLY4 Perhaps they'd like to get enough information to settle the matter?

I think you'd need to see some evidence of knowing and malicious behavior. This would be a drastic step, and even if there was bungling and incompetence, it would be hard to justify the ratcheting up of tensions unless there was some sort of criminal fault.
No formal action will be taken. Certainly not in absence of clear evidence, which is almost not possible as I understand it.
Report that patient zero may have been found. Makes lab leak less likely.

Possible but if so would be done only for political effect and policy makers would have to bend to politics over good sense. The fact is it would have very little effect and cause other actions re China - cooperative or in response to serious misbehaving - more difficult, as in "enough" (e.g. mercantile economic and trade policies). I don't see it as useful, will not change behaviors. So far, the administration appears to be willing to act as if this is an option but no concrete steps.
Adjusting in keeping with the increasing unlikelyhood of a lab leak.

Highly unlikely. While there are several headlines about hospitalized researchers and theories on lab leaks, it would be a leap to formally impose sanctions. It may also serve to be politically counterproductive.
"Speak softly but carry a big stick"

For now there is a low probability. Any sanction based on this matter will trigger a VERY strong reaction from Chinese part, given the spectrum of potential widening implications. A tacit acceptance or a low Chinese reaction could suggest China is responsible for the suffering caused by pandemic. This could push US, China and probably EU and Australia, into a new trade war spiral. All the developed economies are based on a global free trade environment. A large scale trade war will not help, especially coming after the Covid crisis. Economic and social conditions would be negatively affected and the post-Covid positive trend curbed. Secondly, such action should be supported by a strong evidence. Getting this is not possible without China's cooperation and international inspections at Wuhan, which is largely considered as the epicenter of the pandemic. So far China was not open for a dialog on this subject. Even China will change its stance, there is a low probability that any evidence to proof the virus originated from Wuhan laboratory would be found. US sanctions without evidence could create a two-edged precedent. China can also bring the case at Hague international court. An outcome favoring China in a China against US case would oblige US to step back otherwise the sanctions on Russia for Crimea annexation would also come under a question mark. This is only one case. US administration probably will withdraw the sanctions, Bidden isn't Trump. And that would be a bad note for Biden. Probably he has plans for a 2nd mandate. And btw, Biden's counselors might not even like to further push into an action initiated by Trump, which might give him political capital. As of 2021-Jul-7 there are is no public evidence that would indicate a higher probability for this action. Still, there is almost a year till 2022-Jul-1, and the situation might change. A new element that favors a strong Chinese reaction in case of sanctions, Statista has posted a survey showing "Unfavorable Opinions About China Reach Historic Highs", https://www.statista.com/chart/19523/share-with-a-favorable-unfavorable-opinion-of-china/ China will fight back on anything that might bring into discussion any implication in the Covid pandemic otherwise might risk an even further degradation of the current opinions.

This would only happen in tandem with some other events and/or with realization that the virus was really man-made in the Wuhan laboratory. Other scenarios should be something like situation in Taiwan/Hong Kong tightening and mounting evidence of wrong doings in the spread of information about covid-19, or trade war getting tighter because of the bottlenecks in production and the sanctions being used because of covid-19 are really just partly because of it.

China is the number one holder of US debt and a huge US trading partner. Joe Biden may bluster but he is unlikely to actually impose sanctions because it would effect US economic interests. Especially unlikely to happen before the US midterms. Trump who was extreemly anti-China didn't impose any sanctions. I'd also add that I think putting sanctions for COVID19 specifically would require a very high level of proof which is likely not achievable given the UN didn't find anything.
US government already called for open investigation. China already answered "like hell we allow you". This is literally has only one resolution.
Even if conclusive proof is found and announced (big if) then sanctions unlikely. Will be leveraged to improve standards and all part of learnings.
This would set a very bizarre precedent for future pandemics. It seems quite unlikely, less than 1%
Again, given the US’s own history of “accidents” and “mistakes” I find it unlikely they would bother airing another country’s dirty laundry.
This question is tied to the outcome of the question about China being involved w/the spread of Covid from lab instead of natural spread of virus…
Not feasible
There is an increased tension as the US continues the investigations, but also I think Biden is more diplomatic so will try to navigate this thru other channels

China and US have tensions related to trade and/or Taiwan. Without hard proof, USA will be in a weak position to impose any sanctions. 2022 is a year of mid-term elections but stability in USA leadership is vastly improved this cycle.
That'll be happening if there comes out steady prove of lab break. Since Chinese government don't allow investigation from a "neutral" institution unlikely to be proven. If it happened at all.
There's no lab leak. Covid antibodies have been found a year earlier then 12/19

Given the current relations between the US and China governments. I believe there's a good chance of implementing sanctions. The question is what is the objective of those sanctions. My guess is that they will be implemented to put pressure on the Chinese government to study how the virus spread and learn how to prevent, detect or control future pandemics.
As others noted, the evidence would have to be very strong and incontrovertible. The loss of reputation would be more significant than any sanctions directly related to COVID-19.

This question is considerably harder than trying to estimate the odds of an official view on the lab-leak hypothesis. One could reasonably argue that imposition of sanctions is conditional on resolving the lab-leak question one way or the other, but there are complications, of course. - The lab-leak investigation was meant to go on for 90 days, whereas this question has a time horizon of 12 months.
Thanks to @LokiOdinevich / @sebawi / @SE_Meyer / @belikewater for some interesting comments, views and info and tempting me into this one!
Seems unlikely but long time frame creates slim chance. More likely to get public statements condemning actions than actual economic sanctions

There is a long history of Sino-United States diplomacy. While certain factions maybe ignorant of the cultural differences and that history the current administration is not. It would be a counter productive diplomatic stance.

Given current statements from the US government, including leaked news stories, there are no indications that sanctions will be imposed. However, there are several considerations that indicate a probability greater than 0% that are worth following:
Residual % for a very broad question; current situation and trends point overwhelmingly against sanctions in relation to COVID—19.
What a joke: https://edition.cnn.com/2021/03/28/politics/blinken-china-coronavirus-cnntv/index.html h/t @SE_Meyer
Actually, I'm going to go with 0% after all. 3 reasons:
I really think there's 0% chance, but because the Brier penalty for being wrong is so steep, I'll say 2%. I can't picture any measure being passed by the House or Senate.
I think sanctions on the Communist Party would be the most likely, but I don't think it will happen (especially because I believe the Wuhan leak was an accident).

There is a small chance that there was an outbreak, the discovery of which might result in sanctions. The definition is pretty broad, and the time frame pretty long. They are actively investigating this, and something might turn up. This is wild card territory.

No way. Would be the action that carries grave risks and the least benefits. Sanctions on Russia and China ate not existential. Sanctions have crippled Iran and DPR economies Sanctions on the PRC for genocide in Sinkiang can be justified and should be imposed regardless of the power of China. The US must take some action on behalf of the uighurs. It may not accomplish anything but it's all the US and it's allies can do. Until the leaks come out,if they do 20 years from now..we will never be able to establish empirically between lab personnel and Wet Market. Biden is setting up a meeting with Xi Ping and it's in interest of PRC to negotiate with Biden SALT agreements that are possible on wmd especially especially on icbm missiles. We need to demonstrate to Xi Ping that we are well aware of PRC attempt to dominate battle space in South China Sea with area access denial to every US and Japanese ship beyond the first ring of islands as far as Guam, including Taiwan. So PRC will never agree to an INF Treaty.
